EXECUTIVE SUMMARY BAYER MATERIALSCIENCE LLC
NEW MARTINSVILLE PLANT

December 18, 2006

Executive Summary for the Risk Management Rule

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Bayer MaterialScience LLC is committed to the principles of Responsible Care which emphasize operating in a safe and environmentally correct manner. Management systems are in place to assure all facilities are complying with these principles.  There are Corporate Engineering Standards and Health, Environment and Safety Guidelines which address every aspect of Risk Management from design of intrinsically safe processes, to the use of risk assessment, to incident tracking and program audits. Bayer MaterialScience LLC is a Bayer AG company, which is headquartered in Leverkusen, Germany.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC has its own company structure, policies and procedures which are consistent with those of the holding company, but are customized to meet local regulations and standards.  Bayer AG has established guidelines for Responsible Care in Environmental Protection and Safety, which include a Directive for Process and Plant Safety that all Bayer facilities world-wide are expected to follow.  It provides guidance for safe process design and operation.

In the US, Bayer MaterialScience LLC is an active member of the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care Initiative.  Bayer has implemented all seven codes of management practice.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC has a Health, Safety, Environment and Quality Policy which states that it is the company?s responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of its employees, customers and communities.  This is a primary responsibility, of equal importance to any other business objective.  This is supported in the Bayer MaterialScience LLC Visions, Values and Beliefs, which emphasize applying technical expertise to advance our business while assuring the safety and protection of our employees, customers, communitie

s and the environment.

The Bayer MaterialScience LLC New Martinsville facility has implemented all of the corporate Health Environment and Safety Policies and Guidelines through site policies and procedures.  These include site Safety and Health Procedures, Emergency Response Procedures, Process Safety Management Procedures, Hazard Communication Procedures and Risk Management Procedures as well as safety plans in the individual production unit SOPs.

In addition, the Bayer MaterialScience LLC, New Martinsville facility uses the following measures to assure the safety of our chemical processes:

2.  Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled
The primary activities at the New Martinsville facility are towards the manufacture of polyurethane intermediates.  The polyurethane intermediates include aromatic isocyanates like polymeric diphenylmethane diisocyanate.  Polyether and polyester polyols are also produced.  The New Martinsville facility uses or stores eight of the RMP listed chemicals on the site as of December 8, 2006.  Of the eight chemicals covered, five are raw materials, one is an intermediate, one is a finished product, and one is a neutralizing agent for a safety system.  All eight chemicals were modeled using worst case release parameters as a screening exercise to determine the worst case scenario for the facility.  The New Martinsville site TDI plant was shut down and dismantled in 2006. The TDI plant was the location of the worst case and alternative scenarios for phosgene and the alternative scenario for ammonia.  The phosgene and ammonia scenarios a

re also present at the New Martinsville site, polymeric diphenylmethane diisocyanate plant (MR-I).  Phosgene continues to be the worst case scenario chemical followed in order of potential off-site impact by ethylene oxide, toluene diisocyanate, chlorine, propylene oxide, ammonia, formaldehyde, and ethylene diamine.

3.  Worst Case Scenario for the Facility
The worst case release scenario for the New Martinsville facility is the rupture of a phosgene solution vessel. Because of the low storage temperature and the solution concentration, the release to the atmosphere occurs through evaporation from a pool.   Using dispersion modeling (PHAST software), this results in an endpoint distance that reaches offsite receptors. This release assumes no mitigation other than containment in a dike.

4.  Alternative Release Scenarios
Alternative scenarios were developed for all of the RMP chemicals. The alternative scenario for phosgene has the largest potential impact distance of the group. In this scenario it is assumed a leak of 35% phosgene solution develops from the phosgene solution feed system, and is released into the diked area.  However, mitigation limits the release of phosgene to the atmosphere.  Mitigation in this case includes immediate activation of the steam ammonia curtain, and isolation of the line and neutralization of the solution in the dike within 20 minutes.  Under typical weather conditions as suggested in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance the distance to the endpoint reaches offsite receptors.

5.  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The New Martinsville Plant complies with all elements of the OSHA PSM Rule and the EPA RMP Rule.  There are safety procedures, standard operation emergency procedures, accident investigations, hot work and line opening permits, extensive training programs, on-site emergency response teams, vessel inspection programs, and experienced personnel both in the salaried and hourly

workforce.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC is active in phosgene safety initiatives including a corporate phosgene safety committee, Bayer MaterialScience LLC worldwide phosgene safety committee, and is an active member of the ACC Phosgene Safety Panel that deals with phosgene safety issues on an industry-wide basis.

6.  Five Year Accident History
There have been no accidents in the past five years.  There have been no releases in the past five years with off-site consequences.  There has never been any offsite impact from the New Martinsville facility resulting from the release of chemicals listed in the rule. 

7.  Facility Emergency Response Program
The New Martinsville facility Emergency Response System consists of volunteer emergency response teams scheduled on each rotating shift.  There are 185 emergency response team members.  They receive 16 to 50 hours of on-site training annually with some disciplines receiving off-site training as well in specialized subjects, such as fire fighting, rescue, incident command and Hazmat.  An E-Team organization provides secondary support and is staffed by Technical and Managerial Personnel.  The E-Team's main function is to assist and advise the Emergency Response Teams and communicate with outside agencies.  The plant belongs to an industrial mutual aid group called NORIMAC (Northern Ohio River Industrial Mutual Aid Council) that provides mutual aid between the various industries, government agencies, and service organizations in the area.  Community warning sirens are placed in residential areas within 2 miles of the plant and have been in operation, as part of the CAER program, for more than twenty years.
